etymology.description: 金(金) (jīn, 'metal') + 旁(旁) (páng, 'side') = metal object -> currency unit
etymology.interpretation: The character 鎊(bàng) combines 金(金) (jīn, 'metal') representing material substance with 旁(旁) (páng, 'side') for phonetic purposes, indicating a metallic currency unit, specifically the British pound.
etymology.simplification: 鎊(鎊) was simplified to 镑(鎊) by replacing 金(金) (jīn, 'metal') with 钅(钅) (jīn), the simplified metal radical, keeping 旁(旁) as the phonetic component.

examples.chinese: 我带了一些英国镑(我帶了一些英國鎊)，购买纪念品(購買紀念品)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ dài le yīxiē Yīngguó bàng, gòumǎi jìniànpǐn。
examples.english: I brought some British pounds to buy souvenirs.

examples.chinese: 这张票只值十镑(這張票只值十鎊)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè zhāng piào zhǐ zhí shí bàng。
examples.english: This ticket is only worth ten pounds.

examples.chinese: 英国的经济复苏(英國的經濟復甦)，促使镑升值(鎊升值)。
examples.pinyin: Yīngguó de jīngjì fùsū, cùshǐ bàng shēngzhí。
examples.english: Britain's economic recovery has boosted the value of the pound.
